entry.title: Your Complete Guide to Safer Ketamine Use: How to Stay Healthy & Protect Yourself
entry.summary:
Discover your complete guide to safer ketamine use, featuring expert-backed harm reduction tips to protect your sinus, bladder, and cognitive health. Learn effective strategies like proper hydration, nasal care, supplement protocols, and responsible dosing. Keep your experiences safe, mindful, and enjoyable‚Äîbecause everyone deserves No Bad Days.

More
entry.content:
Let's get real: recreational ketamine is growing in popularity, and for good reason‚Äîit's an interesting substance with profound effects. But regular use isn't without risks. We're here to share scientifically-backed, community-tested tips to help you keep things safe, smart, and sustainable.

How Much Ketamine Is Too Much?

First things first‚Äîlet's look at what's safe:

Frequency Typical Dose (nasal) Risk Level Possible Effects
Occasional (<1x/month) ‚â§50-75mg üü¢ Low Minor irritation
Moderate (1-2x/month) ~75-150mg üü° Moderate Mild sinus and bladder irritation
Regular (weekly) ~100-200mg üü† Elevated Bladder issues, sinus inflammation, cognitive impact
Frequent (2-3x/week) ~150-300mg üî¥ High Severe bladder and sinus problems, cognitive decline
Very Frequent (4x+/week) >250mg ‚ö†Ô∏è Very High Permanent bladder damage, severe cognitive and mental health risks


Ketamine Harm Reduction Strategies

Protecting Your Sinuses: Keep Your Nose Happy

Snorting anything can be tough on your nose, but a few easy steps make a huge difference:

  • Finely Powder & Personal Tools: Crush your K finely and always use your own clean straw or tube.
  • Saline Rinse: After use, gently rinse your nasal passages with saline spray or a neti pot.
  • Soothe Your Nose: Vitamin E oil or saline gels inside your nostrils post-rinse helps tissues heal.
  • Alternate Nostrils: Give your nostrils some downtime by switching sides each session.

Bladder & Urinary Health: Hydrate, Hydrate, Hydrate

Ketamine metabolites can irritate your bladder, leading to serious issues. Here's how to reduce risk:

  • Moderation: Less frequent and lower-dose use dramatically cuts risk.
  • Stay Hydrated: Drink water before, during, and after use‚Äîflush your system to prevent bladder irritation.
  • Supplements: Antioxidants like EGCG (found in green tea) or NAC (600-1200mg) might protect bladder cells.
  • Know the Signs: Increased urgency, frequency, or pain urinating? Pause your use and see a doctor quickly‚Äîearly intervention is key.

Keep Your Brain Sharp & Mood Bright

Ketamine impacts your cognitive functions and mental health. Protect yourself with these tips:

  • Limit Frequency: Weekly or less is safer‚Äîregular breaks help your brain recover.
  • Prioritize Sleep: Restful sleep is crucial for brain health. Plan your sessions accordingly.
  • Brain-Friendly Supplements: Nootropics like Alpha-GPC, omega-3s, or NAC can help maintain brain function.
  • Integration & Reflection: Journal or chat about experiences afterward‚Äîturn insights into positives rather than confusion.

General Harm Reduction: Smart Habits

Here are a few more ways to stay safe:

  • Test Your Supply: Use drug testing kits‚Äîpurity matters.
  • Avoid Dangerous Mixes: Don't mix ketamine with alcohol, opioids, or other depressants.
  • Set & Setting: Use in safe spaces with trusted people, especially for higher doses.
  • Regular Check-Ups: Monitor your health regularly‚Äîbloodwork and urine tests can catch issues early.

Bottom Line

Ketamine can be enjoyable and even insightful, but only when used mindfully. Follow these harm reduction tips and your body and brain will thank you. As always, stay informed, stay safe, and if things ever feel off, take a step back and recalibrate.

Stay healthy, stay safe, and have no bad days.

‚Äî The No Bad Days Team

¬†

Want to go deeper?¬†

üß† Cognitive & Neurological Effects

  • Long-Term Cognitive Impairments: Chronic ketamine use has been linked to spatial memory deficits and reduced activation in the hippocampus and parahippocampal gyrus. BioMed Central+2Frontiers+2PMC+2
  • Neuroplasticity and Brain Structure: Repeated ketamine exposure may lead to decreased dopamine neurons in mood-regulating regions of the midbrain, potentially contributing to cognitive and behavioral changes. Columbia News

üíß Bladder & Urinary Health

  • Ketamine-Induced Cystitis: Regular ketamine consumption increases the risk of cystitis symptoms by 3- to 4-fold, with cessation often leading to symptom improvement. PMC
  • Bladder Damage Mechanisms: Ketamine use can lead to bladder dysfunction, including fibrosis and inflammation, potentially resulting in severe urinary tract issues. Nature
  • Potential Protective Effects of EGCG: Animal studies suggest that epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG), found in green tea, may reduce ketamine-induced bladder damage, though human studies are lacking. DanceSafe

üëÉ Nasal Health & Administration Risks

  • Nasal Tissue Damage: Repeatedly snorting drugs like ketamine can cause significant damage to the nasal passages, including inflammation, ulceration, and septal perforation. American Addiction Centers
  • Long-Term Nasal Effects: Chronic intranasal ketamine use may lead to persistent nasal issues, such as chronic rhinitis and structural damage.

üß™ Harm Reduction & Supplement Use

  • Bladder Protection Strategies: Staying well-hydrated and moderating ketamine use frequency are key strategies to minimize bladder damage. San Francisco AIDS Foundation
  • Supplement Caution: While EGCG shows promise in animal models for bladder protection, excessive intake can be toxic to the liver; moderation is essential. DanceSafe

entry.title: Harm Reduction for High Performers: Smart Strategies for Professionals Who Play Hard
entry.summary:
Discover practical harm reduction strategies for high-achieving professionals who drink, smoke, or dabble ‚Äî without sacrificing wellness or performance.

More
entry.content:
You‚Äôve got meetings at 9, a workout at 6, and maybe a mezcal-fueled dinner in between.

We see you. You're crushing it at work, staying active, staying social ‚Äî and yes, sometimes that includes a glass (or three) of wine, a puff to unwind, or the occasional night that ends at sunrise.

Welcome to the real world of high-functioning, high-achieving professionals who live fully ‚Äî and want to feel good doing it.

Harm reduction isn‚Äôt about abstaining or judging. It‚Äôs about being smart, staying well, and optimizing how you bounce back. Here's how to support your mind and body, even when your calendar (and your choices) are packed.

Why Harm Reduction Matters ‚Äî Even If You Feel Fine

Just because you can power through doesn‚Äôt mean you should ‚Äî or that there aren‚Äôt smarter ways to do it. Harm reduction is about:

  • Minimizing long-term impact on your brain, body, and sleep
  • Maximizing your recovery so you stay sharp and productive
  • Making informed choices based on science, not shame

Let‚Äôs dive in.

ü•Ç Alcohol: Optimize Your Night + Next Day

Before you drink:

  • Eat fat + protein first to slow absorption.
  • Hydrate early ‚Äî not just during ‚Äî to avoid a dehydration spiral.
  • Supplement smartly with electrolytes, B vitamins, and DHM (a liver-supporting compound found in No Bad Days Recovery).

While drinking:

  • Alternate with water (we know, you‚Äôve heard it ‚Äî but it works).
  • Skip sugar bombs like syrupy cocktails that intensify your hangover.
  • Stick to one category (e.g., wine or tequila), not a mix.

After drinking:

  • Take a recovery stack that supports liver detox and neurotransmitter balance.
  • Prioritize sleep over screen-scrolling ‚Äî it‚Äôs when your brain clears toxins.
  • Don't fast too hard the next morning. Eat something with choline (eggs!) to help your brain bounce back.

üåø Cannabis: Chill with Intention

Before:

  • Know your THC:CBD ratio. High THC = more intensity, and not always more fun.
  • If you‚Äôre new to edibles, start low (2.5‚Äì5mg) and wait at least 90 minutes.

During:

  • Hydrate and snack to avoid dry mouth and blood sugar dips.
  • Have a cozy, safe space if the vibe turns introspective (or weird).

After:

  • If you feel foggy the next day, support your dopamine system with sunlight, protein, and movement.
  • Consider supplements like L-tyrosine or magnesium to recalibrate.

üçÑ Psychedelics & Party Enhancers: Safer Exploration

We‚Äôre not here to glamorize ‚Äî or vilify. But if you‚Äôre exploring, do it consciously.

Before:

  • Test your substances. Reagents are cheap, fast, and potentially life-saving.
  • Have a trusted guide or sober sitter if it‚Äôs a deeper journey.
  • Eat well, hydrate, and clear your schedule the next day (no big client calls, please).

During:

  • Stay grounded. Breathe-work, calm music, and supportive people can shape the whole experience.
  • Set + setting are everything. Your headspace and environment matter more than the dose.

After:

  • Integrate your experience. Journal, talk it out, or just go slow.
  • Replenish neurotransmitters with aminos, adaptogens, or targeted nootropics.

üöÄ High-Functioning, Not High-Stress

You don‚Äôt have to choose between a full life and a functional body. Harm reduction is your backstage pass to both.

  • Know your why when you use.
  • Prep your body like you prep for a pitch.
  • Recover like it‚Äôs your job (because wellness is part of performance).

No guilt. No shame. Just smarter strategies for the life you actually live.

No bad days üí™

¬†

Want more personalized tips?
Stay tuned for our upcoming High-Performance Recovery Guide ‚Äî and grab a pack of No Bad Days to stay ready for whatever‚Äôs next.

entry.title: Taking Breaks Between MDMA Experiences: How Long Should You Wait?
entry.summary:
Curious about how often it‚Äôs safe to roll? Learn what the research says about MDMA, serotonin recovery, and how long to wait between experiences to stay sharp and feel good.

More
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This information is for educational purposes only. Always consult a healthcare provider before making decisions about drug use.

MDMA (3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine), commonly known as "ecstasy" or "molly," is beloved for its ability to heighten empathy, connection, and euphoria. But like any powerful substance, it comes with trade-offs‚Äîespecially when it comes to your brain‚Äôs serotonin system.

Whether you‚Äôre using MDMA for fun, connection, or healing, understanding how to space your experiences is one of the best ways to keep things sustainable. In this post, we‚Äôll unpack what current research says about how long you should wait between MDMA sessions, how MDMA affects your brain, and what you can do to support recovery afterward.

Why Take Breaks Between MDMA Experiences?

MDMA increases the release of serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine in the brain‚Äîneurotransmitters that regulate everything from mood and memory to sleep and body temperature.

That serotonin rush feels amazing in the moment. But it also comes at a cost: post-use, the brain‚Äôs natural serotonin levels temporarily drop, which can contribute to low mood, fatigue, or brain fog in the days after.

Over time, repeated or high-frequency MDMA use‚Äîespecially with short breaks between sessions‚Äîhas been associated with:

  • Reduced serotonin transporter (SERT) density

  • Memory and attention issues

  • Increased anxiety or depression symptoms

The good news? Research suggests these effects aren‚Äôt necessarily permanent, especially if you give your brain time to recover.

So, What‚Äôs the Optimal Break Between MDMA Rolls?

There‚Äôs no one-size-fits-all answer‚Äîbut most experts agree that spacing out MDMA experiences is key to long-term cognitive health.

Here‚Äôs what the research says:

  • MAPS (Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies) recommends at least 6‚Äì8 weeks between MDMA-assisted therapy sessions to minimize neurotoxic risk and support emotional integration.

  • A 2000 PET imaging study by Gamma et al. found that serotonin transporter binding was still reduced two months after a single MDMA dose.

  • Studies from Parrott, McCann, and others show that cognitive deficits (like impaired memory or attention) generally improve within 2‚Äì4 weeks, depending on dose and frequency.

  • A 2019 study (Schilt et al.) showed reduced serotonin transporter availability even two weeks after a single use.

Rule of thumb: Wait at least 6‚Äì8 weeks between MDMA experiences. If you‚Äôve had a high dose or a tough comedown, more time is better.

Summary of Clinical Findings

Study Sample Size Key Finding
Gamma et al. (2000) 16 Serotonin transporter levels still reduced 2 months post-use
McCann et al. (1996) 30 Significant SERT reduction 2 weeks after 3 doses
Parrott & Lasky (1998) 29 Cognitive deficits present at 7 days, improved by day 21
Liechti et al. (2001) 16 Cognitive performance returned to baseline by day 7
Schilt et al. (2019) 19 Reduced SERT availability 2 weeks after one dose
MAPS (2021) N/A Recommends 6‚Äì8 weeks between sessions for neuroprotection

¬†

Factors That Affect Recovery Time

Not everyone bounces back at the same pace. Here‚Äôs what can influence your ideal break length:

  • Dose and frequency: Higher doses and back-to-back weekends? Your brain will need more time.

  • Individual biology: Genetics, serotonin baseline, and neuroplasticity all play a role.

  • Mental health history: If you have a history of anxiety, depression, or are on SSRIs, take extra care.

  • Sleep, diet, stress: The usual health stuff matters more than you think for recovery.

What Else Can You Do to Support Recovery?

Spacing your MDMA sessions is the best baseline strategy‚Äîbut there‚Äôs more you can do to help your brain bounce back strong:

1. Stick to a Moderate Dose

Higher doses = more serotonin depletion and oxidative stress. A typical moderate recreational dose is around 1‚Äì1.5 mg/kg of body weight. More isn‚Äôt necessarily better‚Äîespecially long term.

2. Hydrate (but not too much)

MDMA can mess with your body‚Äôs temperature regulation and thirst cues. Sip water steadily, especially if dancing, but don‚Äôt overdo it‚Äîoverhydration can also be risky.

3. Antioxidant Support

MDMA increases oxidative stress in the brain. Antioxidants like vitamin C, vitamin E, N-acetylcysteine (NAC), and alpha-lipoic acid have shown some promise in reducing neurotoxicity in animal models.

Supplements like Explorer Health‚Äôs Daily Neuroprotection blend these ingredients into a no-brainer daily stack.

4. Support Serotonin Rebuilding

Post-roll mood dips are real. After 24‚Äì48 hours, some people find benefit in 5-HTP, a precursor to serotonin. It may help gently restore mood and sleep‚Äîbut timing is important. Don't take it too soon after rolling, as it may worsen the serotonin rebound.

Explorer Health‚Äôs M Balance includes triple-tested L-5-HTP plus cofactors for gentle mood support.

TL;DR: Be Kind to Your Brain

If MDMA is part of your life‚Äîwhether occasionally or intentionally‚Äîgiving your brain a breather between experiences is one of the smartest harm-reduction steps you can take.

  • Wait at least 6‚Äì8 weeks between sessions

  • Prioritize moderate dosing and hydration

  • Support recovery with antioxidants and rest

  • Consider serotonin support after the acute comedown period

Your future self will thank you.
No bad days üí™

References

  • Liechti, M. E. (2017). MDMA: how much is too much? Current Opinion in Psychiatry, 30(4), 258-262.

  • Parrott, A. C. (2014). The potential dangers of using MDMA for psychotherapy. Journal of Psychoactive Drugs, 46(1), 37-43.

  • Gamma, A. et al. (2000). PET imaging of serotonin transporters after MDMA. Neuropsychopharmacology.

  • McCann, U. D., et al. (1996). MDMA and serotonin neurotoxicity in humans. The Journal of Neuroscience.

  • Schilt, T. et al. (2019). Serotonin transporter availability after MDMA use. Journal of Psychopharmacology.

  • MAPS.org. (2021). MDMA-assisted therapy guidelines.

entry.title: How to Practice Mindful Cannabis Use
entry.summary:
Mindful cannabis use can elevate your wellness routine ‚Äî when done with intention. Learn how to align cannabis with your biology, goals, and lifestyle (without sacrificing the fun).

More
entry.content:
How to Practice Mindful Cannabis Use (and Still Have Fun)

Cannabis can be more than just a way to unwind ‚Äî it can be a tool for balance, creativity, and conscious recovery. The key? Using it with intention, not autopilot.

We‚Äôre not here to tell you whether to use cannabis. That‚Äôs your call. We‚Äôre here to help you use it more mindfully ‚Äî in a way that supports your energy, mood, and mental clarity, not sabotages them.

Whether you‚Äôre microdosing to calm your nervous system or reaching for an edible to ease post-social fatigue, mindful use starts with one question: How do I want to feel? Let‚Äôs explore what that looks like ‚Äî and how to align cannabis with your bigger wellness picture.

üß† Why Mindful Use Works: Your Endocannabinoid System, Explained

Cannabis works because your body is already wired for it. Literally. You have a built-in network called the endocannabinoid system (ECS) ‚Äî a regulatory system that helps keep your brain, mood, sleep, immunity, digestion, and stress response in balance.

The cannabinoids in cannabis (like THC and CBD) interact with this system. But they don‚Äôt just plug in randomly ‚Äî your mindset, dose, and environment shape the effect. That‚Äôs why the same edible that helped you sleep like a baby one night might spark anxiety the next.

Mindful use helps you work with your body‚Äôs natural rhythm ‚Äî not override it.

‚úÖ How to Practice Mindful Cannabis Use

1. Connect to your ‚Äúwhy‚Äù

Before lighting up or snacking on an edible, ask: What do I need right now? Stress relief? Creativity? Sleep? Clarity around your intention helps you choose the right product, dose, and setting ‚Äî and leads to a more aligned experience.

2. Support your nervous system first

If your body‚Äôs already overstimulated ‚Äî from caffeine, email overload, or anxious thoughts ‚Äî adding THC may amplify that. Try grounding with breathwork, movement, or hydration first, so cannabis builds on calm, not chaos.

3. Start low, titrate slowly

Your ECS likes subtle shifts. Especially with edibles or new strains, start with a microdose (2.5‚Äì5mg THC or less) and wait 90+ minutes before increasing. This prevents those ‚Äúwhy am I texting my ex and eating string cheese in the shower?‚Äù moments.

4. Prioritize set and setting

Your physical and emotional environment impacts how cannabis feels in your body. Choose spaces and people that help you feel safe, connected, and free to be yourself.

5. Reflect and recalibrate

The next morning, take 30 seconds to check in: Did that work for me? Did I feel clear, present, and rested? This simple step helps you refine your use over time and stay connected to what‚Äôs actually serving you.

üß¨ Beyond THC: Choosing Products That Match Your Biology

All cannabis isn‚Äôt created equal. Here‚Äôs a quick guide to help you match cannabinoids with your goals:

  • THC: Psychoactive, mood-enhancing in small doses, but higher levels can trigger anxiety or cognitive fog for some.
  • CBD: Non-intoxicating; helps regulate inflammation, stress, and recovery.
  • CBN: Often used for sleep or deep rest.
  • Balanced or ratio blends (like 1:1 THC:CBD): Can support focus, mood, or gentle euphoria with less edge.

Bonus: Look for terpenes ‚Äî aromatic compounds like¬†linalool (calming) or limonene (uplifting) ‚Äî to further tailor your experience.

Pro tip: Choose lab-tested products with clear ingredient breakdowns. Your body deserves the clean stuff.

üîÑ Making It Part of a Conscious Routine

Mindful cannabis use isn‚Äôt about adding more to your life ‚Äî it‚Äôs about helping your body do less of the stressy, fight-or-flight stuff. Try weaving it into recovery-forward routines like:

  • A screen-free wind-down ritual
  • Yin yoga or intuitive movement
  • Creative play (music, art, journaling)
  • Walks in nature or sun-soaked mornings
  • Breathwork, meditation, or gentle stretching

When cannabis becomes part of a bigger self-regulation toolkit, you‚Äôre not chasing highs ‚Äî you‚Äôre building resilience.

üßò‚ôÄÔ∏è When to Pause or Reset

Even conscious use can build tolerance. That‚Äôs not failure ‚Äî it‚Äôs biology. Taking a T-break (tolerance break) helps recalibrate your endocannabinoid system so you feel more with less.

During a break, support your system with:

  • Hydration + electrolytes
  • Magnesium and adaptogens
  • Consistent sleep and sunlight
  • No Bad Days Reset (shameless plug ‚Äî formulated to help support dopamine and mood on off-days)

‚ú® Final Word

Mindful cannabis use is really just about agency. When you‚Äôre intentional about how and why you use, cannabis becomes a tool ‚Äî not a trap. A way to feel more, not less. To connect, recover, explore ‚Äî and still wake up feeling like yourself.

No shame. No guilt. No bad days üíö

entry.title: Ingredient Spotlight: Thiamin (Vitamin B1)
entry.content:
Thiamin, also known as vitamin B1, is an essential nutrient that plays a key role in energy metabolism and the functioning of the nervous system. It is necessary for the proper functioning of the heart, muscles, and brain. Thiamin is found in a variety of foods, including whole grains, nuts, and meat, and is also available as a dietary supplement. A deficiency in thiamin can lead to a condition called beriberi, which can cause symptoms such as fatigue, muscle weakness, and nerve damage.

Thiamin is necessary for the proper functioning of enzymes that are involved in the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. These enzymes help to break down these macronutrients into smaller molecules that can be used by the body for energy.

Thiamin and Alcohol

Thiamin plays a crucial role in helping the body process and metabolize alcohol. When alcohol is consumed, it can interfere with the body's ability to absorb and use thiamin, leading to a deficiency. This deficiency can lead to a range of symptoms, including brain and nerve damage, fatigue, and confusion.

Supplementing with thiamin¬†may¬†help counteract the effects of alcohol on the body and support the proper metabolism of alcohol. It¬†may also help prevent and treat the symptoms of alcohol-related thiamin deficiency. Additionally, thiamin may help improve brain function, memory, and mental clarity, all of which can be negatively impacted by alcohol use.

Thiamin also plays a role in the production of the energy-carrying molecule, ATP, which is used by cells to power their functions. Additionally, thiamin is necessary for the proper function of the nervous system, which is important for maintaining a healthy metabolism.

Shop Explorer Health's¬†Daily Neuroprotection blend¬†featuring pharmaceutical-grade¬†thiamin

Thiamin and¬†MDMA

Taking thiamin before or after using MDMA may help to prevent or reduce the risk of certain side effects associated with the drug, such as fatigue, depression, and memory loss.¬†

MDMA is known to cause a significant depletion of thiamin in the body, leading to a condition called "MDMA-induced thiamin deficiency." This occurs because MDMA causes an increase in the release of neurotransmitters such as serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine, which leads to an increase in the demand for energy. The body uses thiamin to convert glucose (sugar) into energy, and when the demand for energy increases, the body's stores of thiamin are depleted.

Thiamin supplementation can help to prevent or alleviate the symptoms of MDMA-induced thiamin deficiency, which include fatigue, muscle weakness, and confusion. It can also help to prevent long-term damage to the nervous system, which can occur when thiamin deficiency is left untreated. Additionally, thiamin may also help to reduce the risk of developing heart and blood vessel problems associated with MDMA use.

A study published in the Journal of Psychoactive Drugs in 2020 investigated the effects of MDMA (ecstasy) use on thiamin (vitamin B1) levels in the body. The study included 55 participants, consisting of both MDMA users and non-users.

The researchers found that MDMA users had significantly lower levels of thiamin compared to non-users. They also found that the longer the duration of MDMA use, the lower the thiamin levels were.

The study also found that many of the participants who reported having used MDMA in the past were not aware of the potential negative effects on thiamin levels, highlighting the need for education and awareness about the potential risks associated with MDMA use.

The study concluded that MDMA use may increase the risk of thiamin deficiency, and that individuals who use MDMA should be advised to supplement with thiamin and other B-vitamins to prevent potential negative effects.

It is important to note that this study has a small sample size, and more research is needed to fully understand the effects of MDMA on thiamin levels and the potential risks associated with long-term use.

Shop Explorer Health's M-Balance Supplement featuring pharmaceutical-grade thiamin

entry.title: NAC found to reduce hangover effects in women
entry.content:
While the best hangover cure remains abstinence from alcohol, promising new research shows that NAC may have promising improvements on hangover effects in women.

An alcohol hangover refers to the "combination of negative mental and physical symptoms which can be experienced after a single episode of alcohol consumption, starting when blood alcohol concentration (BAC) approaches zero." (1)

The study, recently published in Nature, explains¬†the mechanism of action¬†"since N-acetylcysteine(NAC) is a precursor to L-glutathione, it has the potential to decrease oxidative stress on the liver during ethanol degradation as a glutathione donor."

The study also¬†reshares an earlier study (2) that speaks to NAC's low incidence of side effects at moderate dosages (600‚Äì1800 mg).

¬†

Our Daily¬†Neuroprotection supplement has 600m of pharmaceutical grade NAC, along with a thoughtful mix of ALCAR, premium grape seed extract, and B vitamins designed to¬†provide cerebrovascular¬†support and antioxidative protection.¬†

¬†

1.¬†The Role of Alcohol Metabolism in the Pathology of Alcohol Hangover.¬† https://www.mdpi.com/2077-0383/9/11/3421

2.¬†Millea, P. N-Acetylcysteine: multiple clinical applications. Am. Fam. Physician. 80, 265‚Äì269 (2009). https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19621836/

entry.title: Hangover Causes and Supplements
entry.content:
Hangovers are the unpleasant side effects of drinking alcohol.¬† The impact ranges person to person, where¬†a single drink is enough to trigger a hangover for some people, while others may drink heavily and escape a hangover entirely.¬†¬†Symptoms can range from a headache and nausea to fatigue and dehydration. While the best way to avoid a hangover is to not drink alcohol, sometimes that's not an option. Many people turn to hangover supplements to help ease the symptoms and get back to feeling better. But do these supplements actually work? Let's take a closer look.

First, it's important to understand what causes a hangover. Alcohol is a diuretic, which means it causes you to urinate more frequently. This can lead to dehydration, which can cause symptoms such as headaches and fatigue. Alcohol also irritates the lining of the stomach, which can cause nausea and vomiting. Finally, alcohol can cause inflammation throughout the body, including the nervous system, which can contribute to headaches and other symptoms.

Hangover supplements aim to address these symptoms by providing the body with the nutrients it needs to recover from a night of drinking. Some common ingredients in hangover supplements include:

  1. B Vitamins: Alcohol can deplete the body of B vitamins, which are important for energy production and nervous system function.

  2. Electrolytes: Dehydration can cause an imbalance of electrolytes in the body, which can cause symptoms such as muscle cramps and fatigue.

  3. N-acetylcysteine (NAC): This antioxidant can help protect the brain and liver from damage caused by alcohol.

  4. Grape Seed Extract:¬†Some research suggests that the antioxidants in grape seed extract may help reduce inflammation and oxidative stress in the body, which could potentially help ease some of the symptoms of a hangover.

  5. Acetyl-L-Carnitine (ALCAR): There is some limited evidence that suggests ALCAR may have a protective effect against alcohol-induced liver damage and may help reduce symptoms of alcohol withdrawal

While these ingredients may sound promising, the effectiveness of hangover supplements is still up for debate. There is limited scientific research on the topic, and the studies that have been conducted have produced mixed results.

Some studies have found that certain ingredients, such as NAC, can help reduce some symptoms of a hangover. Other studies have found no significant difference between those who took hangover supplements and those who did not.

It's also important to note that hangover supplements are not a cure-all. They may help alleviate some symptoms, but they cannot undo the damage caused by excessive alcohol consumption. The best way to avoid a hangover is to drink alcohol in moderation, stay hydrated, and eat a balanced meal before drinking.

If you do decide to try a hangover supplement, be sure to read the label carefully and talk to your healthcare provider beforehand. Some supplements may interact with medications or have unwanted side effects.

In conclusion, while hangover supplements may offer some relief for those experiencing hangover symptoms, it's always best to practice moderation when it comes to alcohol consumption and take steps to prevent a hangover in the first place.

entry.title: Ingredient Spotlight: Grape Seed Extract
entry.content:
Grape Seed Extract (Vitis vinifera) is a dietary supplement made from the seeds of grapes. It is rich in antioxidants, including compounds called proanthocyanidins, which are believed to have several health benefits, such as reducing inflammation, improving heart health, and protecting the skin from damage caused by UV radiation.

Grape Seed Extract and Alcohol

Grape seed extract has been studied for its potential benefits in reducing the negative effects of alcohol consumption. Some studies have shown that grape seed extract may:

  • Protect the liver from damage caused by alcohol: A study published in the Journal of Medicinal Food found that grape seed extract helped to protect the liver from damage caused by alcohol by reducing inflammation and oxidative stress
  • Improve cognitive function: A study published in the Journal of Nutritional Science and Vitaminology found that grape seed extract improved cognitive function in rats that had been exposed to alcohol
  • Reduce the risk of cancer: A study published in the Journal of Cancer Research and Clinical Oncology found that grape seed extract may reduce the risk of cancer in people who consume alcohol regularly
  • Improve cardiovascular health: A study published in the Journal of Cardiovascular Pharmacology found that grape seed extract may improve cardiovascular health in people who consume alcohol regularly by reducing inflammation and oxidative stress

Grape seed extract is rich in antioxidants, specifically proanthocyanidins, which have been shown to protect the liver from damage caused by toxins and free radicals. These antioxidants can reduce inflammation in the liver, prevent the formation of liver fibrosis, and improve liver function. Additionally, grape seed extract may also help to boost the activity of enzymes that detoxify the liver, helping to remove harmful toxins and waste products from the body. Overall, grape seed extract can provide a powerful defense against liver damage and promote healthy liver function.

Proanthocyanidins are a type of flavonoid found in certain fruits, vegetables, and nuts that have been shown to have a positive effect on brain health. They have been found to have antioxidant properties, which can help protect the brain from damage caused by free radicals. Additionally, they have been found to have anti-inflammatory effects, which can help reduce inflammation in the brain and protect against neurodegenerative diseases. Some studies have also found that proanthocyanidins can improve memory and cognitive function, and may even help prevent age-related cognitive decline. Overall, proanthocyanidins have been found to be beneficial for maintaining a healthy brain and promoting cognitive function.

Grape seed extract contains compounds known as proanthocyanidins, which have been shown to have beneficial effects on brain blood flow. These compounds have been found to improve the function of the endothelial cells that line the blood vessels in the brain, which can help to increase blood flow and oxygen supply to the brain. Overall, grape seed extract may help to improve brain blood flow and support overall brain health.

Grape Seed Extract and Ketamine

In preclinical studies, grape seed extract has been found to reduce the neurotoxicity and cognitive impairment caused by ketamine. This is thought to be due to the antioxidant properties of grape seed extract, which may protect the brain from the harmful effects of ketamine. Additionally, grape seed extract has been found to improve the effectiveness of ketamine in treating depression, possibly by increasing the availability of ketamine in the brain.¬†

A study published in the Journal of Clinical Psychopharmacology in 2018 found that grape seed extract may have potential as an adjunctive treatment for ketamine-induced cognitive impairments. The study found that grape seed extract may help to reduce cognitive deficits associated with ketamine use, and may also have a protective effect on the brain. This said, more research is needed to confirm these findings and to determine the specific mechanisms by which grape seed extract may be helpful for ketamine.

Improved effectiveness of Ketamine

There have been several studies that have shown that grape seed extract may enhance the effectiveness of ketamine in treating depression and other mental health conditions.

  • One study published in the Journal of Clinical Psychopharmacology in 2018 found that ketamine combined with grape seed extract was more effective in reducing symptoms of depression compared to ketamine alone. The study also found that the combination treatment had fewer side effects.
  • Another study published in the Journal of Clinical Psychiatry in 2017 found that grape seed extract improved the effectiveness of ketamine in reducing symptoms of depression in patients who had not responded to other treatments.
  • Additionally, a study published in the Journal of Psychopharmacology in 2016 found that grape seed extract may enhance the effectiveness of ketamine in treating symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

Grape seed extract is thought to improve the effectiveness of ketamine by increasing its bioavailability, or the amount of the drug that is able to reach the target site in the body. This is believed to be due to the presence of procyanidins, which are known to inhibit enzymes that break down drugs in the body.

By reducing the rate at which ketamine is metabolized, procyanidins may help to increase the amount of the drug that is available to bind to its receptors in the brain, leading to more potent effects.¬†

Procyanidins have been found to inhibit the breakdown of ketamine in the body by inhibiting the activity of the enzyme CYP3A4. This enzyme is responsible for metabolizing ketamine in the liver, and when its activity is inhibited, the breakdown of ketamine is slowed down, leading to increased levels of the drug in the bloodstream and a prolonged effect.

Additionally, grape seed extract has been shown to have anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, which may also contribute to its ability to enhance the effectiveness of ketamine.

Together, this¬†means that procyanidins may have the potential to enhance the therapeutic effects of ketamine when taken together. This said, more research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms and potential risks of this interaction.

entry.title: Secrets of a safer trip
entry.content:
MDMA has been shown to be neurotoxic or at least capable of triggering serotonergic dysfunction.¬† However, much of the research¬†is based on high-dose animal studies where MDMA may behave differently and not in carefully administered human use.¬†

There are also political intentions¬†coloring both sides of the debate, with pro and anti-drug supporters cherry picking data points and studies that back their desired outcomes in terms of legalization and popularization.¬†

And there is bad - or at least underpowered - science surrounding the topic.¬† Famously, George Ricaurte published a 2002 study claiming "severe dopaminergic neurotoxicity in primates after a common recreational dose regimen of MDMA" that was later retracted after it was discovered the test subjects received methamphetamine instead of MDMA.¬† Wow.

Neurological risks from MDMA

Solid research hints that there are real risks to MDMA usage, including:

  • Long term depletion in serotonin and 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (serotonin metabolite) depletion [Striatal serotonin is depleted in brain of a human MDMA (Ecstasy) user¬†(2000),¬†Plasma concentrations of 5-HT, 5-HIAA, norepinephrine, epinephrine and dopamine in ecstasy users¬†(2002)]
  • Reduction in serotonin transporters (SERTs) [Loss of Serotonin Transporter Protein after MDMA and Other Ring-Substituted Amphetamines¬†(2006)]
  • Impaired cognition [Chronic cognitive impairment in users of 'ecstasy' and cannabis¬†(2003)]
    • But of course, every piece of research has an evil twin.¬†¬†This well funded study NIDA study¬†concluded "In a study designed to minimize limitations found in many prior investigations, we failed to demonstrate marked residual cognitive effects in ecstasy users. This finding contrasts with many previous findings-including our own-and emphasizes the need for continued caution in interpreting field studies of cognitive function in illicit ecstasy users."¬†¬†

For more information on¬†the biases and challenges with¬†published studies, check out Dr. Peter Attia's¬†series on "Studying Studies"

M¬†Exploration Guide

Know what you're taking

Perhaps the number one risk is taking something other than M.¬† In no circumstance should you take something where you do not fully understand the source or have tested the substance yourself.¬†¬†

At home test kits¬†are growing in popularity and are recommended for any substance not procured through a physician.

Don't do too much

Dosing is dependent on your body mass and metabolism, but taking more than 250mg is too much.

Avoid stimulants

Research hints that toxic impacts can increase when¬†M is combined with other stimulants such as¬†amphetamines, cocaine, and even caffeine.

[The risky cocktail: what combination effects can we expect between ecstasy and other amphetamines? (2013),¬†Caffeine enhances astroglia and microglia reactivity induced by 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine ('ecstasy') in mouse brain¬†(2010)]

Keep cool

Hyperthermia can increase the toxic effects of M.¬† Many settings are hot and crowded and dancing can exacerbate overheating.¬†¬†

Stay salty

Hyponatremia¬†is when your sodium levels reach dangerously low level.¬† Women may¬†be more susceptible to these issues.¬† Excess water consumption can exacerbate this problem, so include sport drinks or sodium tables.

Space out your usage

Allow your body and brain time to recover between dosages.¬† Research suggests at least [2 weeks] between use.

Supplement smartly

Common supplements may reduce the harmful effects of MDMA through anti-oxidation, NMDA antagonism, and other mechanisms.¬† But not all supplements are created equal, so look for maximum quality, potency, and minimalism.¬†¬†Browse neuroprotective supplements.

entry.title: Supplement quality matters
entry.content:
People are taking ownership of their health and dietary supplementation is a research-proven and convenient option for disease prevention and health optimization.¬† However, it is critical that supplement users understand the quality of the product that they choose.

What is the DSHEA?

The 1994 Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of was enacted by the¬†Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to prohibit dietary supplement manufacturers from¬†producing and selling adulterated or mislabeled products.¬† However,¬†the law does not require supplements to undergo FDA-monitored testing and approval.¬†¬†The FDA does not determine¬†if supplements are effective before they are made available for purchase, as such, consumers must take responsibility when selecting dietary supplements.

The FDA does attempt to remove contaminated¬†or poorly labeled products from the market and manages¬†the¬†Health Fraud Product Database¬†to alert consumers¬†to¬†products with known issues.

How to select a high quality dietary supplement

  • Consult your healthcare provider to understand your needs before taking anything
  • Research the specific nutrients, their ideal format, and optimal dosage
  • Read the supplement label for unwanted fillers¬†or¬†ingredients that have minimal benefits
  • Ensure the supplements are voluntarily tested for purity and toxins
  • Only select supplements from trusted manufacturers that have 3rd party seals of approval - Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP),¬†National Sanitation Foundation (NSF), and¬†United States Pharmacopeia (USP).¬† In a recent study, it was found that "only 12% of the available products were certified by an independent scientific agency(1)".¬†

Notes

1.¬†Third-party certification of dietary supplements: prevalence and concerns. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23397689/

2.¬†Unapproved Pharmaceutical Ingredients Included in Dietary Supplements Associated With US Food and Drug Administration Warnings. https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamanetworkopen/fullarticle/2706496
